results.title: A Little fable
results.brief_description: An intriguing animated film in which symbolic representation is used instead of realistic drawings. It tells the story of Charlie, an orange boy, whose blue friend is rejected by his mother. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: A Link with our past
results.brief_description: There was a time when the cable car was the pride of many major cities in the Western World, but that was when the pace of life was much slower. However, when major cities started to expand, it became apparent that the demand for some form of short-haul transportation could not be ignored. A young engineer named George Smith Duncan has successfully built a cable tramway in New Zealand. He later moved to Melbourne where he would eventually build the worlds largest cable tram network.

results.title: A Light in nature
results.creator_credit: Stuart Legg, Shell Film Unit and Ramsay Short
results.brief_description: Made on the occasion of the tercentenary of the Royal Society, this film describes the history and achievements of scientific research and indicated what may lie ahead on the borders of science. Studies on the living cell and in radio astronomy are taken as examples of fields in which significant advances may be expected in the future.

results.title: A Lifetime in photography
results.creator_credit: Sandra Ostertag, Holt, Rinehart and Winston, CBS, KOCE-TV (Television station : Huntington Beach, Calif.) and Coast Community Colleges
results.brief_description:
Episode number 20 of Series “The Photographic vision”.
Max Yavno is a photographer whose career has encompassed more than fifty years. Mr. Yavno’s reflections about his career summarizes many of the skills and ideas presented throughout the series.

results.title: A Life Worth Living
results.brief_description: Presents hypothetical case studies of newly born severely handicapped children. A panel of eminent members of the medical and legal professions are asked what their decisions would be in these situations when one human being has the power of life and death over another

results.title: A Life of perfection
results.brief_description: Why does a nun cut herself off from the world in the Service of God? What are the difficulties and joys of living closely together in a Convent? How do nuns try to live a “life of perfection”? In this film photographed at the Roman Catholic Convent of the Sisters of the Assumption, London, and the Anglican Community of the Sisters of the Love of God, Oxford, nuns explain their attitude to their work and the world outside.

results.title: A life in your hands
results.creator_credit: Safe Work Video and Robert Littlewood
results.brief_description: Produced in collaboration with the Ambulance Service, this dramatised first aid video details the steps involved in Cardio Pulmonary Resuscitation (or CPR). A work team operating in a remote area respond to the apparent electrocution of a work mate. No pulse, no breathing. Initially shocked by the event, the workers must remond themselves of the steps involved in both raising the alarm and reviving their workmate. Intended as a reminder of the steps involved in CPR, this video can be used to highlight the importance of the use of CPR in an emergency situation.

results.title: A Life in the day of a cycle courier
results.brief_description: Sarah’s a cycle courier chasing the money, but at what price? Short and succinct this quirky little tale bounces along to the tune of “I Quite Like Girls on Bikes” written and performed by Urban Tramper and His Pack. Features Paige Anderson as girl on bike.

holdings.name: MPEG-2 Digital File; Memory Grid Pod Full Encode

results.title: A Letter to Dad: a Story of Co-Dependency
results.brief_description: This program examines co-dependency. Reluctantly, Megan attends her uncle’s funeral, and in the company of her two cousins, revisits her childhood home. Witnessing Megan’s distress, her cousin encourages her to speak of the effects of her father’s alcoholism on her childhood. This conversation leads Megan to seek a therapist’s help, and during these sessions she realises the important role her past unhappy childhood has had in determining her life. She is eventually able to lay to rest all the anger, grief and guilt that she has been carrying for so long.

results.title: A Letter to Christopher
results.creator_credit: Artransa Park Studios and Kiwi Polish Company
results.brief_description: A classroom study of New Zealand’s native Kiwi - its appearance, habits and ancestry. It has been closely protected since 1908: its export is prohibited except on rare occasions, and it may only be kept in captivity for scientific studies. it has become a national emblem appearing on coins, incorporated in badges, and commonly used in referring to New Zealand’s people. Told by an Australian girl, Susan Boyden.
